2016
Early Access Review
								EDIT: I just can't recommend the game right now due to the lack of players. When the playercount increases to the point where you can fairly easily get into a game with people at similar skill levels to you I'll remove this edit. Just bear in mind the low playercount if you're considering buying the game. Innovative, addictive and incredibly satisfying. Whether you have played for 1 hour or 1,000 hours the awesome feeling you get from being a part of epic plays never fades. The game is quite unpolished but if you can see through the clunky UI and lacking features there is a great game beneath. As with a lot of Early Access games, it's a diamond in the rough.  Supraball in comparison to Rocket League:   "Deathball..." (the predecessor of Supraball) "... was one of the main reasons why Rocket League exists" - Psyonix Adam on Reddit  I expect this comparison is what a lot of people will be wanting to know. I'll preface this section by saying I have about 650 ingame hours in Rocket League and about 2,000 in Supraball.  Rocket League gave me a very similar feeling of excitement that I got from Supraball when I first started playing.  Deep down at their core they are essentially the same game - put the ball in the goal, just with different methods of doing so. Both are very pure, simple games which give you some basic controls and then set you free to do what you wish.  I feel like Supraball gives you a lot more ways to be creative  and play the game though to the degree that every second of the game you are holding the ball the tree of your choices branches 100 times: will you do a little rollspin to juke a defender, will you pass to a teammate who is boosted and flying across the map for a volley combo, will you panic and do a horrible pass back to your keeper and score a hilarious own goal or will you do the countless other things available to you?  More complex plays are also far more accessible in Supraball,  within 100 hours of play you can be setting up strong charge to volley goals to score 300km/h screamer goals, whereas in Rocket League setting up a pass play like this is far, far more difficult.  The autolock pass also makes passing very easy and allows new players to perform teamplay quite easily.  Now let's move onto the pro's and con's of Supraball in it's Early Access State. Pros: +++  Every match plays differently.  There are so many different ways to play that you never end up playing the same game twice. It has the "just 1 more match" feeling and so can be very addictive and has huge replayability. +++  4 unique positions to play: Goalkeeper, Defender, Midfielder and Striker.  You can sink thousands of hours into a position and still have room to learn and innovate. Or, don't conform to the meta, you're free to play however you want!++  The skill ceiling is disgustingly high , I have sunk probably 2000 hours into goalkeeping in the Alpha/Beta and I'm not even close to the skill cap. The skill floor is pretty high too, but even when you first start playing and have no idea what you're doing it is still really enjoyable++ Applying curves and combinations of curves to your shots gives huge variety to the gameplay and  lots of opportunities for creative, unique and flashy plays ++  A short in-game tutorial and some follow up tutorial videos really help you to get to grips with the high skill floor.  The game has alot to learn and the tutorial covers all of the basics, with some sections (such as the goalkeeper training) which are even useful to me with a few thousand hours playtime.+  Intuitive and fairly simple controls  similar to most FPS games+  There's something for everyone . Public matches are more casual and relaxed and ranked is more serious. It's enjoyable to play even if you typically don't like sports games like myself.+ Multiple varients of the 3v3 and 5v5 maps (similar to Rocket League) with different visual styles+ Even if this game does not do too well and has a small playerbase (eg. 50 to 100 players) it can still be fun. The whole time I have played from 0 to 2000 hours there has probably been an average of 40 players online and even so it is a blast. Ehhh: ~Only 2 game modes (3v3 and 5v5) though both gamemodes focus on very different ways of playing~ Curved shots bouncing off of walls are unintuitive but add a huge amount of depth to the game  that allows crazy solo wall jukes and is why the striker position is viable Cons: ---  A clunky UI and missing lots of useful features such as easily partying with friends, good matchmaking and team matchmaking (these features are planned).  The lobby system has matchmaking within it to balance teams but there is no way to easily queue and join a match like you can in Rocket League.--  For some people the optimisation is god awful even on a monster rig, for others the game runs perfectly on a terrible computer.  --  The price is based on the gameplay and potential of future content, not the amount of content it has right now.  This game is priced similarly to Rocket League, but doesn't have any of the extra features. You may want to hold off on purchasing until these features are added if they are important to you.  This problem has been mostly solved by the significant (50% ish) price drop.-The devs "rely on the community renting the majority of servers", which is certainly not something I'm used to in my games and seems very strange to me- Despite what the steam store says  the game is fairly unpolished,  lacking a lot of nice little features like cosmetics or unlockables- Whilst the game can be played by ignoring your teammates, utilising them properly is the best way to play. This might not appeal to some pure solo players-  Some bugs can affect the mid to high level of play,  include random weird bounces off of walls and occasionally your shield not working. These are almost entirely unnoticeable in the first 100 hours of play though and will hopefully be patched tl;dr: It's basically meth Edit: The default controls can be a bit wonky, I would advise changing the following:"Pass" to RMB, "Kick" to LMB, "Pull-Catch" to left shift, "Quickshot" to Middle Mouse. "Shield" to RMB and the others whatever you feel comfortable with. If you want to goalkeep, turn "double tap dash" off and set the "Dash Jump" key to something you feel comfortable with.

								Finding this gem of a game in the summer of 2014 was one the best decisions I've made. No game has given me more pleasure in competing and compelled me to become the best player I can be for my team. I don't think there is another game with the same emphasis on team-play that Supraball has. It's like soccer mixed with hockey but with guns that can shoot the ball really fast with different spins/curves. The graphics may be a turn off for some individuals but I hope that people can look past the cartoon look as there is more to gameplay than just graphics. There are still a few bugs but that is why this is only the early access release and not the final release. I look forward to meeting the newer players and hopefully together we can make this game a competitive e-sport.I urge any new players to watch the tutorial videos or complete most of the in game tutorial. The mechanics of the game are pretty simple, but you can manipulate these mechanics in ways you won't believe at first.* For a starter tip make sure you get familiar with how lock passes work and how your movement affects the route of the ball as it travels toward you.EditThis game has really been struggling with its player base so keep that in mind when you are going to purchase this game (especially if your NA). 4/9/2017: While the playerbase is still struggling a recent update now allows you to get a match within 1 minute against bots.

This is Supraball.Supraball can be enjoyed on a casual level, but competitive Supraball really shines.  Your teammates are counting on you.  Your heart is pounding; your adrenaline flowing.  I have never experienced this from any other video game.The game is in early access.  I look forward to more features, and improved polish.  The gameplay is great, but it still needs features like instant replay to be a great full release.Regardless, I've had years of fun playing Supraball and it's predecessor, Deathball. 								Wall of text! \o/One of the few games I happily spent some money on. However I don't really recommend doing the same thing for new players. But let me explain.I have no clue when did I get hooked into the game. Probably I saw someone streaming the game and decided to try it out. It was free to download, it was in alpha and it was quite fun. A few skilled players taught me the most important moves and tricks and I slowly figured out how these things work. And then I got a Closed beta key for free and after that, we're here.I knew what awaited me when I bought the game. No risk for me (aside from the usual "it's a dead game *hurr durr* waste of money"). I enjoy it because I know what I am, and other players are capable of. As a new player it's risky because you'll either like it or not. A free weekend or a lowered price definitely needed for "the casual" players to try this out.And yes, the price. It's quite high for a game that "lacks content". True! But the developers will add more and more and it will be more diverse, especially if we'll have a bigger community to play with. I bet they're not going to stop right here, when they're halfway through the marathon.The development also seem a bit slow. Maybe they'll release everything at once, and that's why it takes so long? I don't know. However I'm not a programmer, I don't know how hard it is to create a game and new contents so I'm not judging.The early access misses some really needed content, like tutorials. Of course, there's an online "How to play" article which can be found on the official website but who reads that. It would be a really good idea to read it, though... :D You might not know what those things are but after you try those in-game, I'm sure you will figure it out. If not, and you need some advice, most of the skilled players are there to help. We currently have a small playerbase and we surely don't want to lose it because of some confusing game elements.But the core of the game has been layed down for a while now. It's lovely, it's simple and yet so fun if you get a hang of it. Of course you are going to get a bit frustrated if you get knocked out like 10 times in a match because you weren't fast enough with the ball, but as you progress these frustrations will be gone and you start enjoying the game (like I did). You start feeling that you can do better, whatever happened can be done in a different (and better) way even if it was your fault. You'll watch out for it next time. And who knows, maybe you'll score that winning goal or you save a last second shot in a tight match. ^_^Even though there's a few cons about this game and can be considered risky, I definitely recommend this game if you like what you see.EDIT: Fixed some grammar mistakes ( I hope xD ). Thanks for the heads up. o/

A First Person Action Sports Game


YouTube™ Video: [Early Access] Supraball || First Person Action Sports Game 

			Views: 209		

			#Supraball http://store.steampowered.com/app/321400/ Add me on Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/desolater_iv/ Add me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/DESOLATER_IV		

+ The gameplay is a lot of fun. It's similar to Soccer, yet instead of kicking the ball you are shooting the ball out of a energy cannon or deflecting it with a shield. You are able to charge up your shots to shoot faster, and can do a variety of skillful passes and trickshots to make the goals. + Visually the game looks great with some very nicely detailed graphics, lighting, and partical effects+ Loads of various maps to play on with unique themes and sizes+ The tutorial stage does a wonderful job of teaches you how to play in a interactive fun way. One of the best tutorials I've seen from a game.+ Fast paced and exciting. It can feel very rewarding to launch a curve ball across the map and score a goal. This game is in Early Access so don't take these too seriously- Most of the populated servers seem to be EU based (or at least from what i've seen) which seemed to give me lag / very high ping. - I had issues with some of the controls. For example, right click allows you to scoop up or grab the ball from a distance, but at the same time right click also launches the ball. The problem with this is that your character will auto-pickup the ball if it touches you, so when a player passes the ball to you, you may think to right click to grab it, but you end up mistakingly launching the ball. When you are a goalie, you can press shift to dash back and fourth, and ctrl to put up a shield. The problem with this is that it's hard to press shift and ctrl quickly to move and deflect a ball.- High Skill Gap / Learning Curve.... this game requires a LOT of practice, and tutorial videos if you want to get good. Unfortunetely as a noob, I experienced players wanting to kick me due to lack of experience. - No bots, this is bad because if no one is online you can't play the game at all. You also don't have any way to practice to get better unless you can somehow find players of similar skill level.

								Considering there aren't many actual reviews for the game yet and it's averaging around 70 players, I thought I'd add my review to maybe persuade you into buying Supraball. Before I start the review, please know that I am one of the players that have played the game since the beta with the old launcher, so I have a few more hours than steam says I've logged.What is it? As you can tell, Supraball is an eSport game that is soccer with guns. You have 4 jumps which you can use to get around, and have a gun that can shoot your ball, pass it to other teammates, or shield the ball. There are 4 positions to be played, Goalkeeper, Defender (Center Back), Midfielder, and Offense (Striker). Why should I buy and play it?Supraball is a game that is easy to pick up and play! The skill floor isn't high at all, and I've been in servers with many newer players just having fun! If you're looking for a casual game to play with your friends, pick it up and join a practice server and play away! Supraball is also a game with a high skill cap. If you're looking for harder competitive play, there are ranked matches with people that really know the mechanics and how to play the game. Whether you're a more casual or hardcore gamer, this game is for you either way!Not many people are playing it right now - Will I find a match?Yes! I've been on Supraball with as low as only 20 players and with the server browser and matchmaking, I've still been able to join matches as a substitute and found practice matches that were going on.  The community is a friendly one that is most likely willing to teach you and help you learn from any mistakes you make, so don't be afraid to go in there and, have fun, and try your best!--Supraball Review--

Game servers can set the match length, so if it runs a little long for you find a smaller time server.  The game is super fast paced, and kickoffs happen just right after another to keep the action and intensity going.  It's a nifty game that would be difficult to master, there's a lot you can do, and team work is key.  It reminds me a lot of Bombing Run from UT2K4 in the way the gun play is handled.  When you have the ball you can charge a shot to make it go farther, and you get points for shooting it in the net, can't run it in like in Bombing Run.However this game has a key difference in which you can apply all sorts of spin to the ball, and knock other players out.  The spin is applied by hitting Q or E while charing a shot, this gives it air rotation.  If while charing a shot you tap RMB and then Q or E you'll apply spin on the ball when it lands on the ground.  This is useful for getting the ball to your teammates and past goalies.  Combine all that with the fact that you can quad jump and you have a crazy fast-paced indoor soccer arena.The announcer gets super hyped, and games are easy to get in and out of.The second thing to note is the community is not fun to play with sometimes.  However on the same note it's a team based game.  You should try to play with people you know and trust rather than randoms online who may scored on their own goal repeatedly or continuously say nasty things to you.  There's a report button if you need it!Supraball's developers recently changed the XP distribution lately and now defenders and keepers get more points than attackers - of course only if you actually save stuff. A save can get you 25 points, a goal only 20.  So each position is highly valued in the eye of progression and rank.  You don't need to be a striker to stay competitive, goalies are loved as well.

								Table of Contents:- Foreword- Graphics- Gameplay- Sounds- Controls- Quality- Overall Experience-ForewordIm not really a Fan of Football games. I dont like Fifa or any other kind of "real" football game.I played Rocket League which is a pretty good game, but Supraball tops it imo.I've only spent ~50 Hours playing it so far, im still being pretty bad at the game.-GraphicsWell, graphics dont really matter that much in Supraball, its amazing though. I like the design of the Characters, the Menu, they put so much effort into detail on different maps, its just amazing.As i just said, the game is not really about graphics though.-GameplayI really like the gameplay so far, its not really getting boring or anything.The only thing i hate so far are beginners not passing the ball.There is a Training Course (which everyone should play), Online Practice, Regular Matches and Ranked Matches. You require 2500 XP to play ranked which you usally get in 1-3 days, depending on how much you play. XP dont get you anything besides the possibility to play ranked so far, but the game is still in Early Access, so i really think it will be more rewarding in the future.There is not much to say about the gameplay really, its just amazing, you should definetly check it out by yourself!-SoundsThe Sounds in Supraball are just amazing in every way.I especially like the sound the figures make when shooting a goal ^^-ControlsAbout the Controls, they are easy to learn, but hard to master.Its pretty easy for beginners, everything is getting explained to you in the Tutorial.The Tutorial isnt a boring one with some deep Voice talking to you, its just a Practice Course with different Objectives, reaching from Easy to Hard. Even though the game tells you it may take 7 days to learn all of the mechanics, its pretty much done in a few hours. I spent ~3 Hours to complete the course.You can leave anytime and continue where you quit though.-QualityI didnt find any bugs so far, the game looks insanely good though. The Animations are great, just as the graphics and the sounds are. Definetly high quality.-Overall ExperienceMy Overall experience was pretty good. I didnt expect the game to be that good.I got it for free, so my expectations were low, but that game... Don't be salty about losing, because you will adapt overtime and become a more adept player. You have to work as a team, and you have to have fast reflexes. The movement is like that of Unreal Tournament, so 12 year olds be damned. You can strafe dash left and right, and you can quad jump in the air, which is incredibly useful in avoiding a nice kick to the face. You can put a backspin, front spin, or a side spin on the ball, which confuses even the most hardened gods sometimes. Passing is easy too, but it's also very easy to intercept as well, so git gud. All in all, it's a great game with some relation to Rocket League, but don't call it a Rocket League rip off, because this came out before it. See you on the field fam.

Early Access Review
								Aesthetically weak and uninspired, unoptimized, stagnant, feature-starved. These are just a few descriptors that I feel accurately represent the state of Supraball. When buying a new game, I am often curious as to what creative energy went into bringing it to fruition. Supraball is a downgrade from the original mod in terms of art direction. This being the case primarily because Deathball used UT2K4 assets. Deathball had hundreds of user-created maps, a plethora of player models, replays, pausing, and in-game ready system, a more sophisticated kickoff system, better in-game stat tracking, and more gameplay variety. A UT2K4 mod, that had been in development for two years, had far more going on for it feature-wise than a standalone game that has, according to the dev team, been “in the works” for four years. Being a programmer, I understand the challenges behind creating something like this. However, the dev team chose to price the game at $20. Rocket League also costs $20. Rocket League is far ahead of Supraball in almost every area one could think of, and the dev team has invited this comparison via their pricing decision. Gameplay-wise, Supraball is nearly the perfect type of game for me. That I cannot recommend it to most gamers should be a red flag. If you put in the time, a high-level game of Supraball can be more interesting and enjoyable than perhaps any other game I’ve played. It’s that you have to look past the poor art direction, underdeveloped visuals, missing features, nonsensical rank and lobby system, and the very steep learning curve (assuming you want to play in the higher-level games, which is where Supraball becomes far more interesting). In the hands of the right dev team, this type of game could be very successful, as you’ve seen with something like Rocket League. The Rocket League dev team listens to their community, has been a lot of creative energy into their game, and seems to generally “get it”. I cannot say the same for Supraball’s dev team. If you’re looking for something similar to Rocket League in concept, that gives you more control over what’s going on, and has, in my opinion, superior overall gameplay, buy Supraball. Just know that there are several glaring things that you must overlook, and I don’t feel that the vast majority of players are willing to or should have to. If you’re buying this game based on an expectation that it will continue to evolve, don’t. If the game were priced under $10 USD, I feel it would be easier for me to recommend. At $20… No.
